title: The Personal MBA
author: Josh Kaufman
notes: Not sure why I read this - it was so dense. A lot of information that I will never use.

title: The Art Of Travel
author: Alain De Bottom
notes: Didn't like it. I'm probably too dumb to understand Botton.

title: Quiet Power
author: Susan Cane
notes: Didn't quite hit like Quiet.

title: Getting Things Done
author: David Allen
notes: Great book on productivity - I learned a lot!

title: The 7 Habits Of Highly Effective People
author: Stephen Covey
notes: This is another book that I can't recommend enough. A must read for everyone!

title: Do You Talk Funny?
author: Cal Newport
notes: Can't recall much about this book, but the title pretty much sums it up.

title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
author: Yuval Noah Harari
notes: A dense book, but interesting nonetheless. There was a chapter about currency that I still think about years after reading the book.

title: Talking to Strangers
author: Malcolm Gladwell
notes: Glad I picked this one up on Audible - it was part-book, part-podcast. A great read as always with Gladwell.

title: The Great Mental Models Volume 1
author: Shane Parrish
notes: I feel so dumb when I read about mental models and cognitive biases. That's probably the reason I haven't moved on to the other volumes. Very important concepts for clear thinking.

title: Do You Talk Funny?
author: David Nihill
notes: I enjoyed this book and I've been meaning to give it a reread. Picked this one up to improve my humorous speaking at Toastmasters.

title: Mindhunter
author: John Douglas & Mark Olshaker
notes: It started with the series on Netflix. I then went down the rabbit hole of Mindhunter books - they are so dam fascinating to me.

title: An Astronaut's Guide to Life on Earth
author: Chris Hadfield
notes: I didn't realize how much training it took to be an astronaut - super impressed! I will never forget the philosophy around aiming to be zero - great insight. Overall entertaining and a fun journey.

title: Emergency
author: Neil Strauss
notes: There was a sense of urgency to this book, but I found it boring.

title: Killer Across The Table
author: John Douglas & Mark Olshaker
notes: Very disturbing book. I felt ill at some parts.

title: The Cases That Haunt Us
author: John Douglas & Mark Olshaker
notes: As a consumer of true crime, this was an interesting read. The Jon Bene Ramsey case is baffling.

title: The Bomber Mafia
author: Malcolm Gladwell
notes: I'm a fan of war history, so this book was a treat. Great stories and philosophical thoughts about bombing in war time.

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
notes: Probably my favorite fantasy book. I've read it multiple times over the years.

title: The Power Of Vulnerability
author: Brene Brown
notes: Don't recall much from this one, but I recall it being mostly lectures. Brene has a unique and charming personality.

title: On Writing
author: Stephen King
notes: I am a fan of King's work, but I didn't know much about him going in. This was definitely a treat. Had no idea he was hit by a car and survived. Overall, an entertaining read.

title: Models
author: Mark Manson
notes: Thought this was one intriguing, especially after reading The Game. Mark says be yourself, be honest, which is better than pickup artist method, although, it is less entertaining.

title: Caffeine
author: Michael Pollan
notes: Being a caffeine addict, I thought this was an interesting listen. It made me think about quitting coffee, but I don't think that is going to happen.

title: The Evil That Men Do
author: Roy Hazelwood
notes: A dive into the mind of predators. These FBI profiler books are fascinating and entertaining, yet scary as fuck.

title: Extreme Ownership
author: Jocko Willink & Leif Babin
notes: I listened to several podcast with Jocko before I finally made it to his book. The podcasts were memorable, but I do not recall anything from this book besides the title.

title: Endure
author: Cam Hanes
notes: Big fan of Cam Hanes - I love his attitude and work ethic. I thought the book was ok. It was good to learn a bit more about Cam's life, but I don't think he should have wasted any energy on addressing the haters.

title: Inside The Mind Of BTK
author: John Douglas & Johnny Dodd
notes: An insightful look into the mind of a man who was a notorious serial killer, but also a man that had a family and attended church. Appearances are often deceiving, and that's why this book scared the shit out of me.

title: Bittersweet
author: Susan Cain
notes: This one didn't resonate with me.

title: Never Finished
author: David Goggins
notes: Entertaining and motivating.

title: Man's Search For Meaning
author: Viktor Frankl
notes: I've been through this one a few times and recommended it to many friends. This is the type of the book that changes your perspective of the world. A must read for all humans.

title: Brave New World
author: Aldous Huxley
notes: A strange book. Hard not to compare the fictional world in the book to today's reality.

title: Chasing The Light
author: Oliver Stone
notes: A friend recommended this one. Pretty cool to hear how some iconic films were made.

title: Say Nothing
author: Patrick Radden Keefe
notes: A history I was completely unaware of. A fascinating story with a lot of interesting characters. Great writing too!

title: Shake Hands With The Devil
author: Romeo Dallaire
notes: Politics and genocide. I can't imagine having to live through such an atrocity.

title: Greenlights
author: Matthew McConaughey
notes: Entertaining. McConaughey's optimism is infectous.

title: Canâ€™t Hurt Me
author: David Goggins
notes: Very motivating read when I was struggling with running. But now I find Goggins more comical than anything. Stay hard!

title: Atomic Habits
author: James Clear
notes: I have read this one several times and recommend it the most. It has helped me in countless ways.

title: The Psychology of Money
author: Morgan Housel
notes: Another book I have read more than once. I would say this is once of the best books on money out there.

title: The Compound Effect
author: Darren Hardy
notes: Kinda felt like a sales pitch, but a lot of good practical advice. I do agree with the concept of tracking and measuring everything you do. Otherwise, you can't fix what you can't measure. This book validated some of my weird habits around tracking my personal life.

title: Do Hard Things
author: Steve Magness
notes: A book on the benefits of doing hard things. Kinda felt like a lot of this stuff was obvious. Probably read it to validate my running.

title: With the Old Breed
author: E.B. Sledge
notes: Read this while on vacation in Mexico. How it made me feel like a weak man. Haunting account of fighting in the pacific
